What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about poetic canons, literary devices, poetic structure, and the history of poetry. I also learned a lot about the eight poets we studied as people, what influenced their poetry, and of course, analyzed A LOT of poetry this semester!
An overview of English poetry from Pope to present. Learned how to effectively and closely analyze poetry.
This was a fantastic class, especially for Prof. Levine's focus on literary analysis and history.
Critical analysis, prosody comprehension, and general timeline of English poetry.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Levine was an incredible instructor and it's clear how much she enjoys talking about and analyzing these poets and their poetry. The readings she selected for the seminar were diverse (which is super refreshing and awesome to see!), engaging, and helped us trace a clear historical arc, from Pope to Trethewey. The poems selected were also just in general really interesting. 
Weaknesses: There's A LOT of poetry, which is to be expected; the problem is that we often don't get through much of it in class. It'd probably be helpful to focus on certain poems over a lot of poems, but honestly, this is a minor complaint.
Wonderful syllabus with a wonderful professor!

I'm not sure that there were any weaknesses! I always enjoyed going to seminar, where I feel that we engage with the material deeply and in a way that both encouraged engagement and broadened my perspective

Strengths: Improved diversity of poets from previous iterations of this course, variation of assignments (some creative writing of poems, some papers with diverse prompts), very manageable readings for homework, interesting discussion, good feedback on assignments.
Weaknesses: Discussion structured relatively the same each day, which was helpful to know what to expect, but sometimes a bit repetitive; sometimes the discussion questions were a bit too leading, but overall a great class.
Professor Levine is a direct asset to the course and makes material that would normally be intimidating seem manageable and engaging.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course, especially if you can take it with Prof. Levine! It's a super interesting introduction to poetry and the essays don't feel stressful the way Prof.Levine explains them (plus, you get a lot of feedback, which is great and often isn't the case in other courses)!
Yes! Even for non-English majors I think this is a great course if you have any interest in reading poetry.
Definitely, for English majors but also (and perhaps especially) for those who wish to take their first course in the department or who just aren't as comfortable with English.
Yes, if you like English literature and/or poetry... even if you're a bit nervous about taking a poetry class, do it! This class is very accessible and will guide you along the way.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in poetry and literature, and as of one of the required courses for the English majors, it honestly was pretty enjoyable.
